text: the experiential aspect of being there
is so hard to capture and frame the
scale the wind the Sun the enormity of
of the view this is bill Thurid Linsky
for the New York Times
for the hundredth anniversary of herim
binghams encounter of machu picchu I was
assigned to photograph his original
routes through the vehicle bomba valley
my guide was John levers a 59 year old
Australian from a local Cusco adventure
outfitter John has done the strike at
least a dozen times the 60-mile journey
took ten days to complete up and down
countless peaks and valleys our guide
told us that all the elevation changes
were roughly equivalent to climbing and
descending Mount Everest ok yesterday we
came over that Ridge from jockey corral
dropped into the huge Canyon of Rio
Blanco behind that's a real Premack
Canyon in places the trek was rugged but
we didn't exactly rough it we had a cook
and his assistant three Wranglers and
six meals that carried our gear food and
then we averaged about 10 hours of
trekking a day and as we inch our way
forwards the team would raise a head and
have dinner and our camp set up for us
by the time we got there the food was
surprisingly great it's something that
you don't expect on a ten-day camping
expedition our cooking his assistance
with a very few pots and a gas stove
were able to conjure up these
three-course meals what was absolutely
breathtaking was the scale and the
distances that were unveiling in front
of me luckily I had John in the frame
every now and then to give it all some
sense of scale shooting from the trowel
presented its own challenges you either
had to watch your steps not to twist
your ankles or watch the 300-foot cliff
that was just a couple of feet away but
luckily neither I on my cameras fell off
because John said the pace and because
of the steepness of the terrain I ended
up looking at the back of his boots most
of the day
Ed's become a meditative exercise to
watch our step by step
I was warned about blisters about knees
about the adjusting after three-four
days even though I'm in pretty good
shape and I've tracked them through yoga
every day this this scared me luckily I
pulled out a very very very worn pair of
boots the most more Pampas I had and
avoided the blisters miraculously the
first couple of days were enjoyable and
invigorated but how how many days can
you sustain this kind of exertion four
and then by the end turned into a
beautiful monastic almost like
experience leaving such beautiful places
is never easy but it's something you
never forget and I would gladly do again
you
